#FeatureFriday
Every day, our secretaries take hundreds of phone calls from parents and community members. They are the “Voice on the Phone” and in many cases, the main contact point for our schools. We appreciate everything they do to ensure our schools run smoothly and we wanted to shine the spotlight on them. We also wanted to let you “see” and get to know our “Voice on the Phone.”

Harrisonville Elementary Wildcats Attendance Secretary Beth Bullock has been working in our district for six years. She chose to work for the district because she knew it would be fun and rewarding to be part of the #WildcatFamily.

“Most of my days go by very fast, so I must be having fun:-)”

Beth’s favorite part of the job is helping students and their families.

“I love all of the happy waves I get from students who walk by the office!”

Beth’s family includes of a husband, three sons, one daughter and two dogs. When she is not working she enjoys traveling or just finding ways to spend time with her family.

September 2 at 11:50 AM ·

INFORMATION: As we continue our efforts to maintain quality infrastructure for our community, several roadways will be part of the upcoming 2020 road-resurfacing program.
The program will put a layer of micro-surfacing on the roads mentioned/pictured below.
Crews plan to begin working on Tuesday, September 8, and be finished by the end of the day on Wednesday, September 9.

Here is a look at the work schedule:

September 8 -
Ann Avenue, from Chapel Lane to James Street
Elm Street, from Price Avenue to Mechanic Street
Meadow Court, from Crestwood Drive to Hillside Drive

September 9 -
Stacy Road, from Meadow Drive to the end of the culdesac
James Street, from Blueberry Drive to McEowen Elementary School
Galaxy Drive, from Mechanic Street to Elm Street

Over the last few months, some of our staff have not only been continuing their job for the district, but also giving back to the community in a variety of ways. We wanted to shine the spotlight on them & their efforts to support our community as we all work together to ensure the health & safety of the #WildcatFamily.

Harrisonville High School engineering & broadcast teacher Jake Kohl has made face shields using the 3D printer in his classroom.

He said, “I saw there was a need and had the means to do it.”

He’s made 60 face shields for the VA hospital in Kansas City, 20 face shields for Cass Regional Medical Center, 10 face shields for the OPAA employees working the “to go” meal program through the district, and 30 frames for a medical company online that he shipped to California. All supplies were donated. It takes about two hours to print each shield frame.

Proposition N is a no tax rate increase issue for $22,700,000 for providing funds to improve safety & security, replace roofs, HVAC units, and boilers; improve technology and playgrounds, and other repairs & improvements as identified in the Hollis+Miller (architect) facilities needs assessment. Passage would result in a 10 cent rollback of the levy.

For more information on both Propositions I+N, visit our website - www.harrisonvilleschools.org/propsIN.

Since our spring sports seniors are missing their final seasons right now, we thought we could recognize them via social media. Each of them has been sent a survey to complete and we look forward to honoring & celebrating them over the next few weeks. Up next, track athlete Dalton Schrock.

How long have you played this particular sport?
This was my first year participating in track

What's your best memory from playing this sport?
My favorite running memory would be getting 3rd at the St. Jude run in Kansas City

What awards & honors have you earned in this sport?
I did not earn any rewards or honors due to the unfinished season

Why do you enjoy playing this sport?
I miss the sport because it gave me a chance to train till I succeeded in whatever it was that I was trying to accomplish

What do you miss most right now about this sport?
I miss the challenge of training to the desired results

Future plans?
After high school I plan to attend a community college then transfer to Mizzou to major in geological sciences
